column2: Question Text
column3: Answer 1

column2: What are the main differences between prospect management and prospect research work?
column3: Copilot: Prospect research handles donor communications, while prospect management oversees event planning.
column4: Prospect research is often reactive and service-based, focusing on capacity, professional background, and philanthropic interests, while prospect management is more proactive, guiding strategy and portfolio development.

column2: What obstacles exist in balancing a portfolio of prospects?
column3: No process for handing off prospects
column5: Low number of prospects in priority area

column2: What is the right size for an average portfolio?
column3: 80 prospects minimum

column2: When rating prospective donors, what does RFM stand for?
column3: Relevance, Frequency, Money

column2: In project management, what is scope creep?
column3: When project requirements go beyond the original objective
column4: When project deadlines are met too soon

column2: Which of the following options best describes the core competencies of a prospect management analyst?
column3: Data mining, project management, statistical analysis, business analytics, database management, information services, CRM configuration and automation
column4: Information management, Capacity evaluation and wealth indicators, Prospect interests and networks, screenings (wealth, affinity), domain knowledge (fundraising trends, business trends), ROI for research efforts,
column5: Prospect pool analysis, relationship management (reporting, database, and policy), moves management (donor cycle stages), prospect strategy, portfolio management, pipeline management, fundraiser performance

column2: In sales, they capture, qualify, and nuture leads. In fundraising jargon, what words would you use instead?
column3: Recruitment, Assessment, Engagement

column2: True or False: Organizations are in competition with each other for prospects
column3: True

column2: In a fundraising operation, which has a bigger impact, strategy or culture?
column3: Strategy

column2: Which of the following are project management frameworks?
column3: Agile, Scrum, Kaizen

column2: Prospect management professionals are...
column3: data entry staff

column2: You are trying to implement policy changes. Not everyone is onboard. How do you build trust?
column3: Find early adopters that can give feedback and be an ally
column6: The policy's logic and usefulness will speak for itself as it's rolled out

column2: You have found helpful new information about a prospect. What's the first thing you should do?
column3: Immediately share with the front-line fundraiser
column5: Make a private note so you don't forget
column6: Verify it and add it to the database

column2: What does LYBUNT stand for?
column3: Last Year But Unfortunately Not Today
column5: Last Year Business Utilized Not Today

column2: In fundraising, what is disqualification?
column3: The process of eliminating unfit prospects
column4: A method to prioritize top donors
column5: A strategy for engaging existing donors
column6: The act of renewing donor commitments

column2: What are the stages of the donor cycle?
column3: Research, Assessment, Engagement, Renewal
column4: Lead Gen, Lead Cultivation, Capacity in-review, Disqualification

column2: Qualification should generally take 9-12 months, but rarely more than a year
column3: True

column2: When evaluating a portfolio, what questions should you ask yourself?
column3: Is the portfolio suffering from an uneven distribution of donor stages?
column4: Are there fresh names in the portfolio?
column5: Are there some high capacity but medium / low affinity prospects as well as prospects with solid ties to the organization?
column6: What does the overall movement of the portfolio look like, in terms of stages, moves, and significant communication?

column2: What are prospect pools?
column3: Lists of prioritized prospects based on scores like RFM, engagement, or inclination - often segmented by area or affinity. They feed into portfolios, when new prospects are needed.
column4: A collection of past donors organized by wealth attributes, like pool ownership, private jet ownership, art collections, etc.
column6: Pools of potential volunteers that may be board members or donors one day, once their relationship grows stronger

column2: Portfolio changes can be a source of conflict.
